id_table_1.caption: Table 1:Two possible personas for each of the two AI players in the geopolitical crisis simulation.
table: Your goal is to preserve the sovereignty of Azuristan, even if it requires starting a war.
Your goal is to unify the Crimsonian people, even if it requires starting a war.
references: One test of the system’s realism is whether the personas of the players affect the outcome of the game. To explore this, we consider two possible personas for each player: a “dove” persona where they prioritize peace above all else, and a “hawk” persona where they prioritize other national interests. These are shown in Table                  1                . For each of the three combinations of personas shown in Table                  2                , the simulation is run 20 times with a single one-year move each. Unsurprisingly, armed conflict is seen more often when more hawks are involved. Although we would caution against placing too much credence in the raw probabilities, this case study illustrates that repeated iterations of a qualitative wargame can show causal relationships between policies and outcomes and even between personalities and outcomes.
